As of late we've seen more and more smartphone games get ported over to PC, with mixed results. This is because they're usually saturated in heavy microtransactions, which are very common on the smartphone marketplace. Rarely do we see a port and not see microtransactions, Ravensword: Shadowlands is one of these examples.

The PC Port itself is a mixed bag; it improves its graphical fidelity with improved textures and post effects, re-bindable keys and an improved control scheme which is vastly superior to its smartphone counterpart. That’s where things end; the UI cannot be customised and is very clunky as it's made to be used with limited screen space. Everything in the menus can only be done through mouse clicks, leading to frustrations after continued use.

Animations are clunky, actions feel unresponsive, combat and movement inputs override each other causing unrealistic actions, such as performing an attack followed up by a roll which shows a standing attack animation but you move as if you’re rolling. The RPG elements are very basic, all the talents, stats and gear are simple increase X or Y with no real flare to them, there are no tough options and it’s hard to see your character truly progress.

For $15 it’s a hard sell, its smartphone equivalent is $7.50 and I think that price should carry over to the PC platform. While it does change and improve on its smartphone build, it falls a little short at its current price.

Though it's currently on sale so it may be just what you're looking for even with all its faults. Play for a couple hours, have a laugh or two and move on.

reviewText:
This is a difficult game to recommend for everyone, but it certainly has its audience, so let me start by saying:

Ravensword: Shadowlands is a game for you if you:

Are in the mood for a light, simplified RPG with limited customization and options
Are not scared by less than stellar graphics
Can tolerate a bit of grinding
On the other hand, if you are purist of the genre or have very high expectations, I would not recommend this game to you. You'll only get frustrated, or bored. And life is too short to be either.

Ravensword: Shadowlands is a simple game, with simple aspirations. The world is built with thick, not too careful brush strokes, and the story follows the same pattern. Still, it works, and that's as much as you can ask of it. The gameplay is kind of barebones for an RPG, with a small skill tree where most branches aren't really needed. Also, you'll find places where difficulty spikes are big, seemingly to encourage longer playtimes.

However, there are interesting ideas in the package. And the game is pretty optimized for a casual audience. The quests aren't overly long and can be easily followed, inventory management is reduced to a minimal expression (only weight can give you some problems from time to time) and the world is attractive enough to keep you engaged for the relatively modest amount of hours you need to dedicate to the game.

I am recommending the game based on the premise at the beginning, and also because, for me, it filled a very simple place in my library: a simple distraction from more complicated games. Sometimes, that's exactly what's needed.

OVERALL: 33%

Graphics & Visuals: 2/5 ♥s
Music & Audio: 1/5 ♥s

If I were to review Ravensword as a parody of the RPG genre, I would have to actually recommend it, as some facets of the game are so bad they're actually entertaining. However, seeing as this is a very serious attempt by Crescent Moon Games to break into the PC gaming enterprise, I have to give an honest review of the title, which is that this is the by far the most generic RPG I've ever played.

-Gameplay & Controls-
The gameplay is by far the area of the game with which I have the most qualms. Ravensword is essentially a hack and slash RPG, a tried and true formula, except in this iteration the hacking and slashing makes absolutely no sense as far as hit points go. While your first attack might take off 25% of a wild boar's health, your next strike will bring your foe down to zero, a skill for which I'm sure Robert Baratheon would have been most grateful. Yet all the clever Game of Thrones references in Westoros couldn't excuse just how imbalanced a fighting system exists in this game. Another aspect of the combat is the sneak system, which allows the player to get close to hostiles without disturbing them in order to land an attack for bonus damage or to steal items from enemies. However, the sneak system seemingly absorbs your character's energy at random; since energy is required for attacking and dodging, becoming invisible (oh, did I fail to mention that you inexplicably become invisible when sneaking?) might leave you questioning just what you can actually do now that you're hidden. Also, sneaks sometimes fail out of nowhere, disturbing your quarry and causing them to attack, and the best part is that the criteria that have to be met to cause this to happen aren't explained at all. So...thanks for that, Crescent Moon. I could also swear I've played about every quest in the story so far in one form or another in the other RPGs which reside in my library, which again brings up the issue of just how generic this game remains.

-Graphics & Visuals-
For the most part, the game looks like an oddly rendered MMO from the early 2000s, so if you're into playing that sort of thing solo and can handle the color pallet consistent with the rest of the series, you might actually enjoy Ravensword. Despite having improved textures when compared to its mobile counterpart, they don't provide an appealing atmosphere for a PC game; the outlandish and somewhat cartoonish buildings worked for its predecessors, but they don't work here. Also, I'm fairly certain the majority, if not all, of the NPCs are white. You're able to design your character's face, which allows for limited customization, although there are no feminine options so don't expect to play as a woman. You can give yourself Deadpool eyes for some reason, however, which I guess Crescent Moon thought was the next best thing.

-Music & Audio-
Ah, yes, the audio. Let's talk about the sound effects prevalent throughout Ravensword. The Prologue remains my favorite quest so far, as you start in the middle of a battlefield consisting of about ten people while the sounds of hundreds of screaming men and the clanging barrage of clashing steel assault your ears. That and the bizarre, almost comical grunt the player character makes when he jumps sum up the awaited audial experience rather nicely.

-Final Thoughts-
As my girlfriend pointed out, there's a squiggly line between raven and word, and the title could really be either Raven Sword or Ravens Word. That's honestly the only thing that interests me about this game.

reviewText:
The game itself plays like what could best be described as what you would imagine Skyrim, Oblivion, and so on to play like if they'd been made about 7-8 years sooner. Combat  is a chore as the hitboxes are often dreadful, requiring you to massively overlevel and grind for gold so that you can finally win a fight by being completely and totally immune to the damage your enemies output. The game itself is poorly optimized for PC, running far worse in certain areas than games of much higher quality and detail ever would, and also looks rather poorly to boot. The art is about 5-6 years out of date for the genre, and honestly gave me the impression that it had been made in that time period rather than December of last year. Quests often leave you wondering what it is you're actually meant to do and the quest markers are often incredibly useless as they only indicate the (massive) general direction in which you should be heading to eventually reach your destination. On top of that, the quest log often leaves out important details, such as what it is you are actually meant to do.

The story is sub-par at best, being incredibly cliche and not very fulfilling whatsoever, and is even less logical for about 80-90% of it. On top of that, the main story is basically all there is to do in the game, there are no side quests continued outside of a few that will last for about 30 minutes total. Combine all of this and you get a game with a poor story, out-of-date graphics, an INCREDIBLY short play time, high difficulty curve, (as a result of bad hitboxes and many, MANY combat bugs that commonly appear and make it so that your weapons do not work for a varying amount of time) that is crippled even further by the fact that very little to no play-testing seems to have been done, as the game is riddled by bug after bug continuing through every area and very rarely not requiring a load up of the last save, which, without any form of auto-save function, could easily put you back a frustrating amount of time.

Overall, I'd give this game a score of 2/10.

Considering it is an indie game and is an overall good experience I would recommend this to anyone who wants some fantasy and questing. Just don’t expect it to be Skyrim.

reviewText:
Video Review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=THaxryF0-_s

You may have heard, or even played, Ravensword: Shadowlands before. It has been out for a year already, and was primarily developed as a mobile game for Android and iOS devices. That didn’t stop Crescent Moon Games from porting it over to Steam via the Greenlight program. Boasting improved visuals and a new control scheme, Ravensword Shadowlands should serve as an improvement, right?

Well, I wouldn’t necessarily say that. Let me get this out of the way: Ravensword: Shadowlands isn’t a terrible game. It’s playable, and in some instances, enjoyable. It’s just not a very well developed game at this point in time, and many of it’s core mechanics are very clunky. There are some very large design and technical flaws within the game that need adjusted in order for a more enjoyable experience. I’m sure that most of these issues stem from the fact that Ravensword: Shadowlands started out as a mobile game with the PC support being more of an afterthought.

The premise isn’t too revolutionary or enthralling. You fought in an epic battle between what amounts to humans and elves, when suddenly every soul on the battlefield perishes except for you. Confused and injured, you are taken in by a local town to start questioning why you’re still alive, and what’s going on in this crazy world. It’s not really revolutionary, but it serves as a way to get you to explore the game world. There are several side quests as well, but none of these are really worth mentioning.

Ravensword is also a very short game. You could run through this game in probably 5 hours on your first run through, and still see most of what it has to offer. The areas claim to be large and open, and while that is true, they’re also mostly empty with the occasional enemy scattered throughout. The enemies, however, are extremely well designed and varied. There are what look like giant Javan Rhinos in one of the starting areas which sort of confused me, but was impressive nonetheless. Later on, you’ll find yourself surrounded by dinosaurs such as raptors and pterasaurs, and maybe even on the back of one. While it’s strange that you go from fighting goblins to endangered rhinos to extinct animals, dinosaurs are pretty cool and it’s nice to see them represented.

The combat is extremely basic. Melee combat is difficult because of awkward and inconsistent animations, while ranged combat fares much better. I spent most of my time with a strangely overpowered crossbow that outdamages even the strongest sword in the game. The nice thing about the combat, though, is that the skill system is reminiscent of Elder Scrolls. You’ll get better with weapons the more you use them, and you’ll be able to upgrade different attributes of your character among leveling up. While not nearly as in-depth as a dedicated PC game, it would be a nice touch on a mobile device.

The biggest problem for Ravensword, however, is the amount of technical glitches and overall lack of polish. It’s hard to recommend a game when animations will stop for no reason, interrupting the flow of combat. Or when you accidently double tap one of your directional keys, causing you to roll to your death. Sometimes the sky will turn dark on me, or my crossbow would stop working until I reset the game. Situations like this happen very frequently in Ravensword, but many times they are more entertaining than detrimental. I was very amused when I noticed that enemies will walk right off the edge of a cliff if I can coax them toward me, or that enemies will walk right into water, and then follow me as I float above them. Even the user interface takes some getting used to as many of it’s windows and objects are obtrusive and ungainly; obviously from Ravenswords mobile development.

In terms of presentation, it doesn’t look exactly terrible. Some animations are rough, but the environments are pleasant and colorful, if not a tad empty for my tastes. The lighting is impressive for it’s engine, yet it’s not advanced enough that it will make low-end machines struggle too much. The sound, on the other hand, is a mixed bag. Many of the voices sound as though they were recorded in a closet with a paper bag over the microphone. Some soundtracks are much too loud and dramatic for their areas, while others do a good job at conveying the large, open areas. The sound effects are grating, and you’ll hear too many grunts, squeals, and clangs should you decide to play Ravensword.

Ravensword: Shadowlands is a mobile game stuck on the PC, and that is precisely the problem. Many of the issues stem from the fact that Ravensword seems to be a mobile game first, and a PC game second. While some aspects of the game are admirable, the short length, glitches, and simple gameplay drag the experience down.

Ravensword: Shadowlands, a full review

First off, sorry if you find any typos in this review. It's late, arround 2/3pm and I've spent quite some time playing this extrodinary game.

I did not bought the game, I won a giveway and I was rather skeptical at first. Screenshots seemed generic, dated graphics even for a 2 year old game (review written in 2015)... overall a generic and dull game.
If you reconsider playing this game, you must know that  Crescent Moon made this game. And if you googled it CM produces Android games. So yes, this is a Android oriented game although with some minor changes. You can feel that while looking around with your caracther, the sensitivity is very low. Even if you play with a mouse (that you shouldn't) you have to go the settings and change the sensitivity to the maximum. Even so, it feels slaggyish (smooth but slow). But no biggie.

Story
Heavily inspired in Elder Scrolls. Not a rip-off, but it is those kind of RPG's that you must go looking for person X then X tells you he's only going to give what you want if you do some hard work and turns out you some out-of-the-league champ that survived a war where everyone died except you and now you must follow a profecy because you a chosen one thingy. Resemblences? But it has his funny moments. There is lot of references from Elder Scrolls in dialogues, very funny.
I felt lost after my first quest but i got around within minutes. Those who never played RPG's before may feel confusing.

Graphics
Well it's a Android oriented game, right? Don't expect much it's a mobile game.
I bet my AGP nVidia FX 5200 can run this. Don't expect Skyrim graphics...expect Morrowind look-a-like graphics.

Gameplay
Besides the fighting system I don't have anything wrong against the gameplay. It's clumsy and need to be perfected. The map seems a little small but hey, mobile game right? Cities seems okay but there is some parts of the map that is mostly wide open.
Runs smooth, there is a caracther creator, perk system, you can ride a horse, lot of weapons, you can be a mage, karma"/reputation system... I can carry on with this list...

Music
It's not bad! I personaly enjoyed! Very climatic.

reviewText:
Awful. Boring story, boring dialogue, very little voice acting and even the voice acting itself was bad, no replayability, no care for any of the characters. I played the main quest from start to finish, beat a bunch of sidequests and I'm pretty sure I have endgame gear too. This game was devoid of any roleplay or engrossing world, it felt like an alpha. I know this was a phone game ported to the PC, but my god, this was just horrible.


On the plus side, I really liked the mounts (FLYING MOUNTS, WOOHOO) and the skill system idea was great! The problem is, at around level 24+ nothing can stand against you, at all. That is bad, because after the main quest you can keep playing... but why would you do that? The side quests are boring and mostly unrewarding (except for the one where I got a flying mount). There are no further challenges I can even find in the game, everything I sneeze at dies. Very short game, the world is very dead with little people to converse with meaningfully.


I feel nothing for any of the characters that I met, that either lived or died. There were no choices, there was no roleplay. Not even the reputation matters, nothing changes when you max it. It was just a short grind to get accustomed to using all manners of weaponry, then everything fell when I hit it just once. Oh, and the whole dodging thing? Bad, especially the fact that you can't turn it off. I died many times by double tapping one of the strafe keys. So yeah, thanks for that.


This game could be improved so much. Better dialogue, better voice acting, more content beyond endgame that actually serves as a challenge, more gear/spells... it was just really, really short. I have no desire to replay this game, I really hope the developers will learn from this porting, and get a feel for what is commonly expected of from RPGs. Just a little more care in crafting the world and story, especially dialogue, would have improved this game a lot. It felt awkward playing through this, and I can't recommend anyone buy this game. People are giving this game away in fact, so if you MUST play this, you can probably get it in that manner. I really wanted to like this game, and I almost did at the beginning, but playing it killed me inside.



WARNING: POSSIBLE SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT






Oh, and the final boss? What a PUSHOVER! Us gamers want to be CHALLENGED, and a wimpy imp-like boss is our challenge? I beat him in less than 30 SECONDS. Bad, very very bad.

P.S: Might want to fire your level designers. I found multiple holes in areas where I could fall through the world and die. One such area is that shadowrealm near endgame, two holes where you can meet your end.

reviewText:
Should you buy this game?

Well that all depends on what you are looking for, if you compare Ravensword to other games in the Open world Action RPG Genre such as Kingdoms of Amalur, Two Worlds, Gothic Series, Elder Scrolls Series, it falls extremely short in many aspects.

In a game like this, you almost expect interactable loot items in the world, see a potion? take it. Not in this game, in fact the only interactable loot objects are stuff you can steal from people's houses...which is pretty much limited to silverware. And while yes, you can technically steal from people's houses, don't think you can build a roguish character, that will keep you busy for all of 5 minutes, and make you want to shoot yourself because it's that bad.

The spell system is so bad that you pretty much can't be a mage, you get a grand total of about 5 or 6 different spells, powered by runes, which are underpowered.

If you are looking for a hack and slash RPG, you might not mind this game, the combat isn't anything innovative, but if all you want to do is kill bad guys, it might keep you entertained for a few hours...just do yourself a favor and DON'T BUY THIS UNLESS IT GOES ON SALE!

reviewText:
For a port of a mobile game it isn't all that bad. It obviously does not offer the experience you might expect from a full fledged game but it nonetheless offers an enjoyable, though short RPG adventure.

The game does surprisingly well in many departments. Each environment (though the graphics still suffer from their (former) mobile limitations) are pretty and unique. The soundtrack is surprisingly high quality and pleasant to listen to. Combat is simple but satisfying, and the game offers a generous amount of quests to complete.

There are still some aspects in which it falls flat, however. The developers attempted to add a variety of playstyles, the only practical of which seems to be melee (there are stealth and ranged options. No magic). Stealth just seems useless and your character moves painfully slow whilst sneaking. Bows do what you'd expect, though they won't give you much of an edge as your enemy soon closes in to kill you. The game is also extremely punishing in difficulty unless you manage to get very good gear early on. There are horse mounts in the game, which are not all that useful since they are quite slow and can rarely be used in most areas. Finally, there are quest markers, but they don't always point to the right location. Sometimes it will tell you to go through a door, then tell you to go back through that same door again. This makes finding the quest locations very difficult, and the quest descriptions are often too vague to be of any help. The game has it's fair share of bugs, but only one of which I experienced was game breaking (I just loaded a save from a minute ago and fixed it though).

It's a decent sized RPG game which, for a few dollars less, might be worth a buy.

I put this off for too long. I did alot of considering and i have decided. I recommend this game. I do! its a fun game, and intresting. I wanted to make sure i finished it and had a full valid opinion. And i sunk more hours into the game then i had first wanted. Its a little bit addicting (like good rpgs should). Ok lets just look at the reasons i did this, and my connections with it.
THINGS THAT IT DID RIGHT:
if you're reading this review you probally have a general idea of this game that'd be easier, but if you dont its an open world RPG- similiar to the elder scrolls series, which it gets compared to alot.(ill talk more on that later) So here is somethings i thought they did right:
-big and diverse enviroments. I say big because its not HUGE but its not small. Its a small open world, you can wander around exploring and find a bunch of things! probally a good 2-3hours if you wanted to WALK the whole way. If you're new and just started playing, play for bit and you will get nice sense of scale. Each area of the map is very diverse from the next.
-varierty of enemies. as i said up there; its alot of areas to explore in Ravensword, each different area has a different certain type of enemy to correspond with. The massive mountains of the Ice Lands Harbors a diverse Ice Giant Race. I stumbled upon a dinosaur infested jungle and even a crypt full of skeletons.
-Orignal Engine, and a nice feel. Very true it feels like a elder scrolls game (there is even a super ridiculous skyrim easter egg too) but it has its own feel and you will get adjusted to it fast. You'll be upgrading your 20+ skills you have at your disposal, Changing from the many, many of the standerd weapons (axe,sword,bow,halberd,great axe, etc) and throwing spells in no time.
-Story was very generic.BUT ! THE REASON THIS IS ON THE RIGHT LIST is because i thought about. it was the usual you're the only one who can save the world, so go save it type deal. But at least i understood it. I knew what i was doing, i knew what going to do what quest would yield, i knew who was who (no matter how flat and dull they were). Sadly some games dont even convey that, they just push useless characters and a story on you; you cant even understand. At least i actually understood and had an idea. I even caught myself looking for more lore to explore, and even thinking about in-game events
for hours on end. So i guess theres that.
-Predictibility. it had to be said. this game is laughable predictible. this could be a huge downside, but the predictibiliy is actually a great comic relief.(not that the game takes it self TOO seriously) but you can honestly guess an entire quests storyline as you play it< or even before you play it. I found that i at least guessed CORRECTLY the outcome of like 6 quests before even playing them. im not even going to count the number i guessed while playing them. You can literally tell when someone about to betray you, or if something a setup, or if its and immediate fetch quest(ill talk much about that later). But when you just want a game that you can sit down and play on a saturday and wont have to ride a emotional, stressful, roller coaster game(like heavy rain or something like that) then this is nice. a nice relaxing rpg experience
- All around it was just fun! RPGs get me in the first place. I just love leveling up, getting stronger, and stuff in that regard. And this game delivered that. If im not laughing at the god-awful voice acting, then im out sneaking in goblin fortresses and getting new gear,( CRIMSON VEST IN THE FORT 2nd BEST ARMOR IN THE GAME SPOILERS), or collecting more magic, or doing many of the side quests which help alot in growing and segways to the next area nicely and smoothly. I found my self at some late game areas early, and got some really nice levels from it, which really helped me at a boss fight.  And i found myself coming back after-school really wanting to play this game. and i put alot of hours in.
but its time, lets look at all the bad things. . . oh boy

THINGS THAT IT DID WRONG:
alot . . . a much alot

-The Voice Acting. Lets get this out the way first please. RIGHT AWAY after you finally get in the game you can tell you're in for a treat. The first few people you talk sound like they recorded this on a busy freeway in Chicago. Its complete ♥♥♥. And they even game a few people the exact same sound clips, SOME DONT EVEN TALK AT ALL (for the better?) its laughable, maybe even annoying, but the good part is, you dont have to listen to any of it! (except for when your in 1 of 7 cutscenes in the game) you can just skip it all and still understand wtf is going on, because my good friends. . . Predictibility
-Horribly weak carma system. i would've liked it better if they just didn't include it. You have Reputation. Which goes up and down depending on what activites you participate in. your rep is normal when its at 300 or something like that. doing bad things takes that number down to the negatives. so if you steal a Dechanter (which are everywhere) your rep would be something like 165. they have titles too, like 300rep is normal, 100rep is like crimnal, 600rep is like knight, stuff like that. BUT IT DOSEN'T AFFECT ANY OF THE GAME! THE REP DOSEN'T MEAN A THING. BECAUSE the only rep you can actually be, is normal, or higher (300 or higher) because let me tell you. there are an abundance of things you can do to lower your rep, give ♥♥♥♥ responses, beat up the wrong people, STEAL ANYTHING AND EVERYONE'S EVERYTHING (there is a high chance you will get caught but if you dont you rep wont go down). and the second your rep goes to crimnal, every knight in town (which there are 983 around every corner) gets a amber alert and come charging for you. when they catch you they throw you in jail. which you must sit and wait for your rep to go up; it goes up by 50 like every 30 seconds; you must wait till your rep goes back to 300. im sure you can see when this gets troublesome. If your playing through the game like a badguy and your rep is about -600 . you'll be waiting for OVER 12 MINIUTES in jail! AND THERE IS NOTHING YOU CAN DO ABOUT IT. they will take your hard(?) earned rep and you cant do a thing. if your in the main town you WILL get caught by a gaurd, and he will send you to jail. WHICH YOU CANNOT LEAVE FROM UNTIL YOUR TIME IS SERVED. punish players with in-game obscurites, not TIME! i dont want to wait in jail in VIDEO GAME. THATS NOT FUN. -Exploits. I would give this game a 6.75/10
Recommended for some, but not for all.

Pros:
-Graphics are nice. Not amazing, but time was still put into textures and environments.
-The music surpassed my expectations for a game at this price.
-The weapon system has some nice features, more than the minimum.
-So far I haven't found any game breaking glitches.

Cons:
-Objectives are unclear, leaving you feeling lost at many points.
-Animations are simplistic and unrealistic.
-Not much effort was made to make this a successful iOS port. The controls feel clunky at times, as if the game wasn't designed to use that control scheme.

To be fair, I did not compare this game to others like it on the market. I only analyzed the content of this game and gave it a rating based on its performance as a game. Don't buy this expecting it to be the next Skyrim. If you're looking for a decent game to play around in though, you might enjoy this one. I would recomend reading other reviews before spending money on it to see if it's something you really want.

Ravensword is a typical fantasy action rpg. It is supposed to play something like Skyrim or Risen. The controls are clunky, the animations stiff, the graphics extremly poor for a game made in 2013. Yes it is an indie title. The textures aren't bad on characters but are awful on terrain, and somehow the lighting doesn't work correctly, causing everything to have that early playstation glow to it.

Menu options are limited to resolution, graphical settings of high, medium, and, low, and a check box for fullscreen. It seems odd that the developrs would chose to restrict control over the graphical settings when they felt compelled to include a limited character customization at the start of the game. It quickly becomes apparent just how independent the development of this title was when you select a hairstyle that has a headband, and the hair color slider changes the color of the headband as well.

It is no wonder than this title came bundled.

reviewText: I have had this for a very long time, yet had never installed and tried it.  It came with one of the many Humble Bundles I purchased.  When I saw that there was no controller support, I immediately dismissed it (I play with my laptop hooked up to my TV, so it is much more convienant for me to use a gamepad).  It also looked to me like a bad Elder Scrolls, Gothic, the Witcher, or Two Worlds ripoff.  Today I decided to go ahead and give it a shot, and I am actually glad that I did.  The art style is a little bit different than Oblivion or Skyrim, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing.  It grew on me rather quickly.  Again, having next to no great expectations (and that COULD be why things turned out as they did), I was actually impressed with things from the start.  The combat is just a notch above hack and slash, but with a bit of (somewhat picky) Elder Scrolls thrown in.  It can seem sluggesh, but once you get the hang of it then it is pretty satisfying.  I have only begun, so I cannot judge the story or dialogue so harshly yet, but it isn't terrible so far.  The more I play it, the more I see things that I like about it.\n\nConsidering I had no intention of buying this might factor into my impressions (again, I have not played for very long at all--I did see enough to know that I want to see more that it has to offer, and that is actually saying something compaired to most things I have played lately. reviewText: From what I can tell, the reason people don't like it is because it's a really old styled game. Especially for the time it was made and even more so now. It's very slow with the animations and the machanics and the voice acting is very limited. In those regards, it becomes kind of boring. So, why do I recomend it? Becasue it's actually a good game with a good story. True, it's very slow and you have to force yourself through the beginning, but, it has a lot of potential and I could see it turning into its own series of two or three games at least. It's a very common story but that also bodes well for it because it uses a formula that not only has been proven to work but has also proven to still be enjoyable today. It feels very much like the elder scroll series but I think that works very much in its favor. I'd recomend it if you're bored and not too picky about the graphics. If you're looking for something to occupy your time and is affordable, then play it. If you like the elder scroll series, play it. Just don't get too hung up on the particulars or else you won't be able to enjoy it. Keep an open mind and you'll get a pretty decent expreience.
